references: At the beginning of a time slot, a user will send a content request to the edge node if a certain content file cannot be found in its local cache. Though much closer to the users, the edge nodes have limited caching and computing capabilities compared to the cloud server. As such, the edge nodes can only store some selective — usually most popular contents. Whenever the requested contents are not located in the edge nodes, the request will be further forwarded to the cloud via the backhaul link. Additionally, definitions of key notations used in this paper are given in Table I for ease of reading.

references: In the trials, the parameter set 𝒢isubscript𝒢𝑖{{\cal G}_{i}} and the transition probability matrix 𝐏i={Pgl​gki}gl,gk=0Gisubscript𝐏𝑖superscriptsubscriptsuperscriptsubscript𝑃subscript𝑔𝑙subscript𝑔𝑘𝑖subscript𝑔𝑙subscript𝑔𝑘0subscript𝐺𝑖\mathbf{P}_{i}=\left\{P_{g_{l}g_{k}}^{i}\right\}_{g_{l},g_{k}=0}^{G_{i}} of each UE-i𝑖i are generated randomly, where Pgl​gkisuperscriptsubscript𝑃subscript𝑔𝑙subscript𝑔𝑘𝑖P_{g_{l}g_{k}}^{i} represents the transition probability from αglisuperscriptsubscript𝛼subscript𝑔𝑙𝑖\alpha_{g_{l}}^{i} to αgkisuperscriptsubscript𝛼subscript𝑔𝑘𝑖\alpha_{g_{k}}^{i}. In particularly, the entries of 𝐏isubscript𝐏𝑖\mathbf{P}_{i} can be arbitrary values, as it has no impact on the algorithm performance. As such, the statistical properties of the user behaviors are non-i.i.d. Under these parameters, users record their requests Fi​(t)superscript𝐹𝑖𝑡{F^{i}}(t) over a period of time. Then, each UE-i𝑖i randomly extracts S𝑆S samples (𝐱is,𝐱is)superscriptsubscript𝐱𝑖𝑠superscriptsubscript𝐱𝑖𝑠({{{\bf{x}}_{i}}^{s}},{{{\bf{x}}_{i}}^{s}}) from its own request record as the training dataset 𝒯isuperscript𝒯𝑖{{\cal T}^{i}}. In addition, we evaluate the performance of the proposed URFL algorithm on small groups of users, i.e., I∈{3,6,10}𝐼3610I\in\{3,6,10\}, which is also adopted in [53, 54]. Adam optimizer [55] is used to train the parameters {Θi}i=1IsuperscriptsubscriptsuperscriptΘ𝑖𝑖1𝐼\left\{\Theta^{i}\right\}_{i=1}^{I} with an identical adaptive learning rate starting from 10−4superscript10410^{-4}. It should be emphasized that 𝒢isubscript𝒢𝑖{{\cal G}_{i}} and 𝐏isubscript𝐏𝑖\mathbf{P}_{i} are merely assigned to establish a similar-to-real simulation environment, neither of them are known to the MEC server and the UE-i𝑖i itself. For the architecture of the deep encoder ΘEisuperscriptsubscriptΘE𝑖\Theta_{\textrm{E}}^{i} in the URFL, we use three hidden layers with 128128128, 646464, 242424 LSTM neurons as well as a dropout rate of 0.350.350.35 in each hidden layer to avoid overfitting. A mirror-symmetrical structure of the encoder is implemented in the decoder ΘDisuperscriptsubscriptΘD𝑖\Theta_{\textrm{D}}^{i}. Detailed simulation parameters are listed in Table II.

references: The performance comparisons between the proposed method and all the baseline algorithms versus the number of total content files N𝑁N are presented in Fig. 9. It can be seen from Fig. 9 that the proposed URFL algorithm significantly outperforms all the baselines regardless of the value of N𝑁N. The statistics of communication cost represented by the data traffic in the MEC network are listed in Table III, where I=10,N=24,T=32formulae-sequence𝐼10formulae-sequence𝑁24𝑇32I=10,N=24,T=32. Though we can observe from Table III that the proposed URFL algorithm generates more data traffic for its offline training than the other baseline methods, the offline training phase is often implemented when the UE is idle, i.e., dormant status, charging status, etc. Therefore, it is acceptable for the proposed method to reduce the error of popularity prediction and preserve the privacy of users by sacrificing the tolerable increase of data traffic in the idle status of the MEC network. Moreover, under the assumption that ∀i∈ℐ,Ci​(t)=∅,λi​(t)=1formulae-sequencefor-all𝑖ℐformulae-sequencesubscript𝐶𝑖𝑡subscript𝜆𝑖𝑡1\forall i\in\mathcal{I},C_{i}\left(t\right)=\emptyset,\lambda_{i}\left(t\right)=1, the theoretical data traffic of all the considered methods per time slot are equal, but the proposed method can achieve the lowest prediction error. When the assumption is invalid in the real environment, the data traffic of the centralized methods still remains 40​B40B40\;\rm{B}. By contrast, the data traffic of the distributed methods will be less than 40​B40B40\;\rm{B}, which actually depends on the λi​(t)subscript𝜆𝑖𝑡\lambda_{i}\left(t\right), prediction errors of local/global popularities, and the cache hit rates of each cache entities.

references: As for the sampling estimate, we set up 6 users and respectively record their requests Fi​(t)subscript𝐹𝑖𝑡{F_{i}}(t) over continuous 100000 time slots, where the parameter set {αi​(t),λi​(t)}superscript𝛼𝑖𝑡subscript𝜆𝑖𝑡\left\{\alpha^{i}(t),\lambda_{i}\left(t\right)\right\} of each user are randomly generated and remain constant during this period. Besides, the number of total contents N𝑁N is set to 32. Then, we count the number of times that each content Fn∈{F1,F2,⋯,FN}subscript𝐹𝑛subscript𝐹1subscript𝐹2⋯subscript𝐹𝑁F_{n}\in\left\{F_{1},F_{2},\cdots,F_{N}\right\} has been requested according to the recorded requests data. Finally, according to Borel’s law of large numbers [44], we observe the requested frequency of each content and acquire the sampling estimate of 𝐏G​(t)superscript𝐏G𝑡{{\bf{P}}^{\rm{G}}}(t) by approximating 𝐏G​(t)superscript𝐏G𝑡{{\bf{P}}^{\rm{G}}}(t) from these frequencies. On the other hand, the theoretical value of 𝐏G​(t)superscript𝐏G𝑡{{\bf{P}}^{\rm{G}}}(t) can be directly calculated by Theorem 1 under this given scenario. Moreover, in the experiment, we consider the case that the local popularity follows four different probability distributions respectively, i.e., Zipf​(αi)Zipfsuperscript𝛼𝑖{\rm{Zipf}}\left(\alpha^{i}\right), Poisson​(li)Poissonsuperscriptli\rm{Poisson}\left(l^{i}\right), nBernoulli​(pi)nBernoullisuperscriptpi\rm{nBernoulli}\left(p^{i}\right), Gaussian​(μi,σi)Gaussiansuperscript𝜇isuperscript𝜎i\rm{Gaussian}\left(\mu^{i},\sigma^{i}\right). αisuperscript𝛼𝑖\alpha^{i}, lisuperscript𝑙𝑖l^{i}, pisuperscript𝑝𝑖p^{i}, {μi,σi}superscript𝜇𝑖superscript𝜎𝑖\{\mu^{i},\sigma^{i}\} respectively represent the distribution parameter of user i𝑖i under these four probability distributions. Specifically, the parameter settings in this statistical experiment are listed in Table IV. From Fig. 15, we can observe that the gap between the sampling estimate and the theoretical value always stays negligible under different distributions, which validates the Theorem 1 intuitively. Besides, as shown in Fig. 15, the gap is also quantified by the RMSE metric to further validates the Theorem 1.
